I'm completely OK with this sort of battlespace enhancement.

I'm NOT saying we should be deploying fully autonomous weapon systems.  But, where we keep humans in the decision loop (e.g. remote operators) then it gives us a big advantage in warfighting.

Both fighters and commanders have to worry about friendly casualties.  But with "fearless" weapon delivery platforms this consideration is largely removed.  These unmanned platforms dramatically change the economics of warfare by significantly reducing human risk.

Even in an an asymmetric battlespace, the advantage shifts toward the fearless.

Um, yeah.  Autoloaders have been around since about 1940 for land-based AFVs and guns, and far longer in naval service.  Not to get overly technical, but AFV autoloaders usually carry their ammo in the turret basket, which poses the risk of explosion if the armor is penetrated. (See photos of disabled Russian tanks in Ukraine)  The time advantage from autoloading in a modern tank is quite small.  That's why most western tanks don't use that tech, and rely more on precision than rate of fire.

There's much less concern with a "robotic" AFV - no crew, more compact, more available weight for armor.
